monogr.title: The pityfull histori [e] of two louing Italians, Gaulfrido and Barnardo le vayne : which ariued in the countrey of Grece, in the time of the noble Emperoure Vaspasian. And translated out of Italian into Englishe meeter by John Drout, of Thauis Inne Gentleman. Anno. 1570
monogr.author: Drout, John

div.head: ¶The Preface to the Reader.
div.p:
BEholde (gentle Reader) hovve I haue depainted and set forth vnto thee this vvofull historie of tvvo Italians (al for thine ease as I hope) vvhiche by thy diligente reading thou shalt finde them nothing at all inferiour (concerning true amitie) to the tvvo Turtles Titus and Gisippus, and that thou shalte thinke them vvorthie to be receyued into the troupe: or to bee committed amongest the crue vvhiche are already rehearsed of maister Vnderdonne: also I haue as greate admiration (as euer he had) vvhat they should bee that do not reioyce to heare of the vnspeakable freindshippe and amitie vvhiche vvas betvvene Orestes and Peliades, Theseus and Perithous, Achilles and Patrocles, Nisus and Eurialus, Castor and Pollux, Damon and Pithias Achates and Aeneas, Alexander and Ephestio, Celius and Patronius, C. Lelius and Scipio Affricanus, Darius and Megabisus, and last of all, that be not glad to heare of our Gaulfrydo and segnior Bernardo, vvho for true amitie maye be annexed and adioyned vvith the rest. VVherefore (gentle Reader)
I considered vvith my selfe that I vvas one of the moste that coulde do least, for the vvhich cause, I vvoulde very gladly haue yelded vp vvholly this storie (beeing but lately come forth) to some other of my acquaintaunce vvhich might haue done it farre better (than possible I haue done at this tyme.) But beyng in a maner partly coacted by a speciall frende of myne (to bevvray this my small skill vnto thee) I toke it vpon me the boldlyer: In hope vvhen as thou shouldest (at thy leysure) conferre the one vvith the other, then thou vvoldest iudge fauourably, and correcte friendly: and to saye vvith Terence, that Nihil est iam dictum, quod non sit dictum prius. Thus leauing of to trouble thee any further, I committe it to the correction of the learned. Vale.

q.l: Reade ere thou iudge, then iudge thy fill▪
But iudge the best, and mende the yll.
